words.definition: to deny the existence or truth of; to nullify
sentences: His actions negate everything he claims to believe.
The evidence negates the defendant's alibi.

words.definition: failing to take proper care; careless
sentences: The negligent driver caused a serious accident.
She was negligent in her duties as a caretaker.

words.definition: a person who is new to a subject or activity; a beginner
sentences: As a neophyte in the field, she had much to learn.
The neophyte struggled with the advanced techniques.

words.definition: to irritate or annoy someone
sentences: His constant complaints began to nettle his coworkers.
The unfair criticism nettled the young artist.

words.definition: very small; existing in name only
sentences: They charged only a nominal fee for the service.
He held a nominal position with no real power.

words.definition: appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety
sentences: She remained nonchalant despite the stressful situation.
His nonchalant attitude annoyed his worried parents.

words.definition: a sentimental longing for the past
sentences: The old photographs filled her with nostalgia.
He felt nostalgia for his childhood summers at the lake.

words.definition: famous for something bad; widely known for negative reasons
sentences: The notorious criminal was finally captured.
The restaurant is notorious for its slow service.

words.definition: new and original; not like anything seen before
sentences: The scientist proposed a novel approach to the problem.
Her novel ideas impressed the entire committee.

words.definition: a person new to or inexperienced in a field or situation
sentences: The novice made several beginner mistakes.
As a novice cook, she followed recipes exactly.

words.definition: a subtle difference in meaning, expression, or sound
sentences: She understood every nuance of the complex argument.
The translator captured all the nuances of the original text.

words.definition: to make legally void; to cancel out
sentences: The court voted to nullify the unfair contract.
His poor performance nullified all his earlier efforts.

words.definition: to care for and encourage growth or development
sentences: Parents nurture their children through difficult times.
The teacher worked to nurture each student's talents.

words.definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
sentences: The obdurate manager refused to listen to suggestions.
Despite all evidence, he remained obdurate in his beliefs.

words.definition: to make unclear or confusing; to obscure
sentences: The politician tried to obfuscate the real issues.
Technical jargon can obfuscate simple concepts.

words.definition: not influenced by personal feelings; based on facts
sentences: Scientists must remain objective in their research.
She gave an objective assessment of the situation.

words.definition: required by law, rule, or custom; mandatory
sentences: Attendance at the meeting is obligatory for all staff.
The obligatory safety inspection was completed.

words.definition: not direct or straightforward; indirect
sentences: He made an oblique reference to the scandal.
Her oblique approach confused everyone in the meeting.

words.definition: not aware of or concerned about what is happening around one
sentences: She was oblivious to the danger around her.
He remained oblivious to the hints she dropped.

words.definition: not clearly understood or expressed; unknown
sentences: The meaning of the ancient text remained obscure.
He quoted an obscure philosopher no one had heard of.

words.definition: excessively eager to please or obey; servile
sentences: The obsequious assistant agreed with everything the boss said.
His obsequious behavior irritated his colleagues.

words.definition: no longer in use or no longer useful; outdated
sentences: The old software became obsolete within two years.
Many skills from the past are now obsolete.

words.definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or action
sentences: The obstinate child refused to eat vegetables.
His obstinate refusal to compromise ended the negotiations.

words.definition: slow to understand; lacking sharpness of intellect
sentences: He was too obtuse to understand the subtle joke.
The obtuse student needed extra explanation.

words.definition: to remove or prevent a difficulty or disadvantage
sentences: The new design will obviate the need for repairs.
Careful planning can obviate many potential problems.

words.definition: to block or close up; to obstruct
sentences: The blockage occluded the blood vessel.
Clouds occluded the sun during the eclipse.

words.definition: extremely unpleasant; causing hatred or disgust
sentences: The dictator's odious crimes shocked the world.
She found the odious task impossible to complete.

words.definition: asserting authority in an annoyingly domineering way
sentences: The officious clerk demanded extra paperwork.
His officious manner made him unpopular with coworkers.

words.definition: suggesting that something bad is going to happen; threatening
sentences: Dark, ominous clouds gathered on the horizon.
There was an ominous silence before the announcement.

words.definition: having unlimited or very great power
sentences: The emperor believed himself to be omnipotent.
No leader is truly omnipotent in a democracy.

words.definition: involving heavy obligations or responsibilities; burdensome
sentences: The onerous task took all weekend to complete.
The contract contained several onerous conditions.

words.definition: not transparent; difficult to understand
sentences: The opaque glass blocked all light.
The legal document was opaque to the average reader.

words.definition: a person who exploits circumstances for personal gain
sentences: The opportunist took advantage of the crisis.
Politicians are often seen as opportunists by the public.

words.definition: rich and luxurious; lavishly abundant
sentences: The opulent mansion had twenty bedrooms.
They enjoyed an opulent lifestyle abroad.

words.definition: to speak formally and at length
sentences: The senator orated for two hours on the topic.
He loved to orate about his favorite subjects.

words.definition: elaborately decorated; highly detailed
sentences: The ornate ceiling took years to complete.
Her ornate writing style was difficult to read.

words.definition: following traditional or established beliefs or practices
sentences: He took an orthodox approach to teaching.
The orthodox methods were challenged by new research.

words.definition: to move back and forth; to waver between opinions
sentences: The pendulum continued to oscillate steadily.
She oscillated between accepting and declining the offer.

words.definition: characterized by showy display meant to impress others
sentences: His ostentatious wealth made others uncomfortable.
The ostentatious wedding cost millions of dollars.

words.definition: to exclude someone from a group or society
sentences: The community decided to ostracize the troublemaker.
She felt ostracized after the misunderstanding.

words.definition: done or shown openly; not secret or hidden
sentences: His overt hostility made everyone nervous.
The overt discrimination was illegal and wrong.

words.definition: to bring peace to; to calm or soothe
sentences: The mother tried to pacify her crying baby.
Officials worked to pacify the angry crowd.

words.definition: done with great care and thoroughness
sentences: The restoration required painstaking attention to detail.
Her painstaking research took over five years.

words.definition: acceptable to the taste or mind; agreeable
sentences: The chef made the healthy food more palatable.
The compromise was palatable to both sides.

words.definition: pale, especially because of illness or fear; lacking vitality
sentences: His pallid face showed he was not feeling well.
The pallid performance disappointed the audience.

words.definition: able to be touched or felt; easily perceived
sentences: The tension in the room was palpable.
There was a palpable sense of excitement before the game.

words.definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
sentences: There is no panacea for the country's economic problems.
Education is often touted as a panacea for poverty.

words.definition: a typical example or pattern of something; a model
sentences: The discovery created a new paradigm in physics.
Her work became the paradigm for future research.

words.definition: a statement that seems contradictory but may be true
sentences: It is a paradox that standing still can be progress.
The paradox puzzled philosophers for centuries.

words.definition: a model of excellence or perfection
sentences: She was considered a paragon of virtue.
The company became a paragon of corporate responsibility.

words.definition: an outcast; a person despised or rejected by others
sentences: After the scandal, he became a social pariah.
The country was treated as a pariah by other nations.

words.definition: having a limited or narrow outlook; provincial
sentences: His parochial views showed his limited experience.
The parochial attitudes of the town surprised visitors.

words.definition: an imitation for comic effect or ridicule
sentences: The show was a clever parody of political debates.
His parody of the famous speech made everyone laugh.

words.definition: a strong supporter of a party, cause, or person
sentences: The partisan refused to consider opposing views.
Partisan politics prevented any compromise.

words.definition: easily recognizable; obvious
sentences: The patent lie fooled no one.
His patent disregard for rules got him fired.

words.definition: arousing pity; miserably inadequate
sentences: The abandoned puppy was a pathetic sight.
His pathetic excuse convinced no one.

words.definition: to treat in a condescending way; to be a customer of
sentences: She hated when people patronized her.
We patronize local businesses whenever possible.

words.definition: the presence of something in small or insufficient quantities
sentences: The paucity of evidence made the case weak.
There was a paucity of qualified candidates.

words.definition: a small, relatively unimportant offense or sin
sentences: The minor peccadillo was quickly forgotten.
Everyone has a few peccadilloes in their past.

words.definition: excessively concerned with minor details or rules
sentences: His pedantic corrections annoyed everyone.
The pedantic professor focused too much on grammar.

words.definition: lacking inspiration or excitement; dull
sentences: The pedestrian writing bored the readers.
His pedestrian ideas failed to impress the committee.

words.definition: expressing contempt or disapproval
sentences: The term has a pejorative connotation.
She used pejorative language to describe her opponents.

words.definition: a strong liking or tendency toward something
sentences: She has a penchant for expensive shoes.
His penchant for risk-taking worried his family.

words.definition: engaged in deep or serious thought
sentences: She sat in pensive silence by the window.
The pensive student stared at the ceiling.

words.definition: extreme poverty; destitution
sentences: The family lived in penury for years.
His gambling addiction led to penury.

words.definition: lasting for an indefinitely long time; enduring
sentences: Pollution is a perennial problem in the city.
The perennial favorite won the award again.

words.definition: deceitful and untrustworthy; treacherous
sentences: The perfidious ally betrayed them at the worst moment.
His perfidious nature made him few friends.

words.definition: carried out with minimum effort or interest
sentences: He gave a perfunctory nod and continued working.
The perfunctory inspection missed several problems.

words.definition: relating to the edge; of secondary importance
sentences: The issue was peripheral to the main discussion.
He caught a glimpse in his peripheral vision.

words.definition: the offense of lying under oath in court
sentences: The witness was charged with perjury.
Committing perjury can result in prison time.

words.definition: to spread throughout; to penetrate
sentences: The smell of coffee permeated the entire house.
Fear permeated the small community after the incident.

words.definition: having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual way
sentences: The pernicious rumors destroyed his reputation.
Smoking has pernicious effects on health.

words.definition: to make something continue indefinitely
sentences: The myth was perpetuated through generations.
We must not perpetuate harmful stereotypes.

words.definition: confusing or puzzling; difficult to understand
sentences: The perplexing puzzle took hours to solve.
Her behavior was perplexing to everyone.

words.definition: a special benefit or privilege connected to a job
sentences: A company car was one of the job's perquisites.
The perquisites of the position made it attractive.

words.definition: to continue despite difficulty or opposition
sentences: She persevered through years of hardship.
Those who persevere often achieve their goals.

words.definition: relevant or applicable to a particular matter
sentences: Please share only pertinent information.
Her questions were pertinent to the discussion.

words.definition: to make someone anxious or unsettled
sentences: The strange noise perturbed the sleeping baby.
Nothing seemed to perturb the calm instructor.

words.definition: to read or examine carefully and thoroughly
sentences: She perused the contract before signing.
He perused the menu for several minutes.

words.definition: to spread through and be present in every part
sentences: A sense of gloom pervaded the office.
The scent of flowers pervaded the garden.

words.definition: spreading widely throughout an area or group
sentences: Technology has a pervasive influence on modern life.
The pervasive smell of smoke lingered for days.

words.definition: childishly sulky or bad-tempered
sentences: The petulant child refused to share his toys.
Her petulant response surprised everyone.

words.definition: seeking to promote the welfare of others; charitable
sentences: The philanthropic organization built schools in Africa.
Her philanthropic efforts helped thousands of families.

words.definition: having an unemotional and calm disposition
sentences: The phlegmatic accountant rarely showed excitement.
His phlegmatic nature helped him stay calm in crises.

words.definition: devout religious belief and practice
sentences: Her piety was evident in her daily prayers.
The community valued piety and tradition.

words.definition: the highest point of achievement or development
sentences: She reached the pinnacle of her career.
The discovery was the pinnacle of his research.

words.definition: to make someone less angry or hostile; to appease
sentences: He tried to placate the angry customer.
Nothing could placate the furious mob.

words.definition: calm and peaceful; not easily upset
sentences: The placid lake reflected the mountains perfectly.
She maintained a placid demeanor throughout the crisis.

words.definition: sounding sad and mournful
sentences: The plaintive cry of the seagull echoed.
She sang a plaintive melody about lost love.

words.definition: a remark or statement that has been used too often to be interesting
sentences: His speech was full of boring platitudes.
She offered only platitudes instead of real advice.

words.definition: seeming reasonable or probable; believable
sentences: Her explanation seemed plausible at first.
He gave a plausible excuse for being late.

words.definition: a direct vote by all eligible citizens on an important issue
sentences: The government held a plebiscite on independence.
The plebiscite showed strong public support.

words.definition: an excess or overabundance of something
sentences: There was a plethora of options to choose from.
The plethora of information made deciding difficult.

words.definition: easily bent or flexible; easily influenced
sentences: The pliable material was easy to shape.
Young minds are more pliable than older ones.

words.definition: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret
sentences: The movie had a poignant ending.
Her poignant words moved everyone to tears.

words.definition: involving strongly critical or controversial writing or speech
sentences: The polemical article sparked heated debate.
His polemical style won him many enemies.

words.definition: slow and clumsy; dull or laborious
sentences: The ponderous bureaucracy slowed everything down.
His ponderous writing style put readers to sleep.

words.definition: to be a sign or warning that something will happen
sentences: Dark clouds portend a coming storm.
The economic data portends a recession.

words.definition: having great power, influence, or effect
sentences: The medicine was potent and worked quickly.
She made a potent argument for reform.

words.definition: dealing with things in a practical, sensible way
sentences: She took a pragmatic approach to the problem.
The pragmatic solution saved both time and money.

words.definition: an earlier event that serves as an example or guide
sentences: The court ruling set an important precedent.
There was no precedent for such a decision.

words.definition: a general rule intended to regulate behavior or thought
sentences: Honesty is a basic moral precept.
She lived by the precepts of her faith.

words.definition: to cause something to happen suddenly or sooner than expected
sentences: The scandal precipitated his resignation.
Rising tensions precipitated the conflict.

words.definition: to prevent from happening; to make impossible
sentences: The injury precluded him from playing.
His busy schedule precluded any vacation time.

words.definition: having developed certain abilities at an earlier age than usual
sentences: The precocious child could read at age three.
Her precocious talent amazed her teachers.

words.definition: something that comes before and indicates another will follow
sentences: The telegraph was a precursor to the telephone.
Mild symptoms can be a precursor to illness.

words.definition: a preference or special liking for something
sentences: He has a predilection for Italian food.
Her predilection for adventure led her to travel.

words.definition: having the most power or influence; most common
sentences: Blue was the predominant color in the painting.
The predominant view was in favor of the change.

words.definition: surpassing all others; very distinguished
sentences: She was the preeminent scholar in her field.
The preeminent authority on the subject agreed.

words.definition: to take action to prevent something from happening
sentences: The company preempted the competition with a new product.
Security measures preempted the attack.

words.definition: a statement or idea on which reasoning is based
sentences: The premise of his argument was flawed.
We accept the basic premise of the theory.

words.definition: the quality of being greater in number, quantity, or importance
sentences: The preponderance of evidence supported her claim.
There was a preponderance of young people at the rally.

words.definition: failing to observe proper limits; excessively forward
sentences: It was presumptuous of him to give advice.
Her presumptuous behavior offended the hosts.

words.definition: attempting to impress by affecting importance or culture
sentences: The pretentious restaurant had tiny portions.
His pretentious attitude alienated his peers.

words.definition: to prove more powerful; to be widespread
sentences: Justice will prevail in the end.
Common sense finally prevailed.

words.definition: widespread in a particular area or at a particular time
sentences: The disease is prevalent in tropical regions.
Such attitudes were prevalent in the past.

words.definition: existing at or from the beginning of time; fundamental
sentences: The primordial soup gave rise to life.
He felt a primordial fear of the dark.

words.definition: in its original condition; unspoiled
sentences: The beach remained pristine and untouched.
She kept her collection in pristine condition.

words.definition: a state of lacking basic necessities
sentences: The family endured years of privation.
War brought privation to the entire region.

words.definition: the quality of having strong moral principles; honesty
sentences: Her probity was never questioned.
The judge was known for his probity.

words.definition: a tendency to choose or do something regularly
sentences: He has a proclivity for telling jokes.
Her proclivity toward perfectionism caused stress.

words.definition: to delay or postpone action
sentences: Students often procrastinate on their assignments.
Stop procrastinating and start working.

words.definition: spending money or resources freely and recklessly
sentences: The prodigal son wasted his inheritance.
Her prodigal spending led to bankruptcy.

words.definition: remarkably great in extent, size, or degree
sentences: She possessed prodigious musical talent.
The project required a prodigious amount of work.

words.definition: showing disrespect for sacred things; blasphemous
sentences: His profane language shocked the audience.
The profane act outraged the religious community.

words.definition: competent or skilled in doing something
sentences: She became proficient in Spanish.
The proficient programmer fixed the bug quickly.

words.definition: plentiful; abundant in amount
sentences: She offered profuse apologies for the mistake.
The garden was profuse with colorful flowers.

words.definition: to increase rapidly in number; to multiply
sentences: Weeds proliferated in the neglected garden.
Social media platforms have proliferated in recent years.

words.definition: producing much fruit or many works
sentences: The prolific author wrote thirty novels.
The prolific artist produced hundreds of paintings.

words.definition: using too many words; tediously lengthy
sentences: His prolix speeches bored the audience.
The prolix document needed serious editing.

words.definition: important; well-known; standing out
sentences: She was a prominent figure in politics.
The building occupies a prominent position downtown.

words.definition: to make widely known; to put into effect officially
sentences: The government promulgated new regulations.
The church promulgated its doctrine to the faithful.

words.definition: an inclination or natural tendency to behave in a certain way
sentences: He has a propensity for getting into trouble.
Her propensity for honesty was well known.

words.definition: accurately predicting what will happen in the future
sentences: His warning proved to be prophetic.
The prophetic words came true years later.

words.definition: to win or regain the favor of by doing something pleasing
sentences: He tried to propitiate his angry wife.
The sacrifice was meant to propitiate the gods.

words.definition: a person who advocates for something
sentences: She was a proponent of environmental protection.
Proponents of the bill gathered signatures.

words.definition: the state of being correct and proper in behavior
sentences: She always acted with the utmost propriety.
The comment violated all standards of propriety.

words.definition: lacking imagination; dull and ordinary
sentences: The prosaic explanation disappointed the dreamers.
His prosaic writing lacked any creativity.

words.definition: to forbid or condemn as harmful
sentences: The law proscribes such discriminatory practices.
The religion proscribed eating certain foods.

words.definition: the state of being successful and wealthy
sentences: The country enjoyed years of prosperity.
Hard work led to their prosperity.

words.definition: lying face down; overcome or helpless
sentences: He lay prostrate on the floor in exhaustion.
The heat left everyone feeling prostrate.

words.definition: to prolong or extend in time
sentences: They tried not to protract the negotiations.
The illness protracted his recovery for months.

words.definition: making provision for future needs; prudent
sentences: Provident planning saved them during hard times.
The provident investor saved for retirement.

words.definition: narrow-minded; unsophisticated
sentences: His provincial attitudes reflected his isolated upbringing.
The provincial town had little cultural diversity.

words.definition: arranged or existing for the present; temporary
sentences: The provisional government lasted only a year.
She received a provisional license to practice.

words.definition: to stimulate or incite someone to do something
sentences: His comments provoked an angry response.
She tried not to provoke her brother.

words.definition: nearness in space, time, or relationship
sentences: The proximity of the school was convenient.
Their proximity made collaboration easy.

words.definition: acting with care and thought for the future
sentences: It would be prudent to save money now.
The prudent decision avoided further problems.

words.definition: showing great attention to detail or correct behavior
sentences: The punctilious host attended to every detail.
Her punctilious nature made her an excellent editor.

words.definition: having a sharply strong taste or smell
sentences: The pungent odor of garlic filled the kitchen.
The cheese had a pungent flavor.

words.definition: a person who insists on absolute adherence to rules
sentences: Grammar purists object to split infinitives.
The purist refused to accept any changes.

words.definition: a difficult, complex, or hazardous situation
sentences: The project became a bureaucratic quagmire.
They found themselves in a legal quagmire.

words.definition: a state of uncertainty about what to do
sentences: She was in a quandary about which job to accept.
The ethical quandary troubled him deeply.

words.definition: complaining in a petulant or whining manner
sentences: The querulous patient complained constantly.
His querulous tone annoyed everyone.

words.definition: in a state of quietness or inactivity
sentences: The volcano has been quiescent for centuries.
The market remained quiescent during the holiday.

words.definition: representing the most perfect example of a quality
sentences: He was the quintessential gentleman.
The cafe was quintessentially Parisian.

words.definition: exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
sentences: His quixotic dreams of world peace never faded.
The quixotic plan had little chance of success.

words.definition: a consequence or result of an action or event
sentences: The ramifications of the decision were far-reaching.
Consider all the ramifications before acting.

words.definition: flourishing or spreading unchecked
sentences: Corruption was rampant in the government.
The rampant growth of weeds ruined the garden.

words.definition: bitter, long-lasting resentment; ill will
sentences: There was no rancor between the former rivals.
Years of rancor poisoned their relationship.

words.definition: aggressively greedy or grasping
sentences: The rapacious businessman exploited his workers.
Rapacious landlords charged excessive rents.

words.definition: to give formal approval or consent to
sentences: The senate voted to ratify the treaty.
Members will ratify the new constitution.

words.definition: making a harsh, loud noise; rowdy
sentences: The raucous party kept neighbors awake.
Raucous laughter filled the crowded bar.

words.definition: extremely hungry; voracious
sentences: After the hike, they were ravenous.
The ravenous wolf devoured its prey.

words.definition: to reject or refuse bluntly
sentences: She rebuffed his attempts at friendship.
The proposal was rebuffed by the committee.

words.definition: to express sharp disapproval or criticism
sentences: The manager rebuked the employee for being late.
She rebuked him for his careless mistake.

words.definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
sentences: The recalcitrant student refused to follow rules.
Recalcitrant employees were difficult to manage.

words.definition: to withdraw or renounce a statement or belief
sentences: The witness was pressured to recant his testimony.
He refused to recant his controversial views.

words.definition: to respond to an action by making a similar one
sentences: She hoped he would reciprocate her feelings.
The country reciprocated with its own trade sanctions.

words.definition: a person who lives in solitude and avoids others
sentences: The wealthy recluse lived alone in the mansion.
He became a recluse after his wife died.

words.definition: to restore friendly relations; to make compatible
sentences: The couple tried to reconcile after the argument.
She struggled to reconcile her beliefs with reality.

words.definition: little known; abstruse; dealing with profound matters
sentences: The recondite subject interested few students.
His recondite knowledge impressed the scholars.

words.definition: to put right; to correct
sentences: The company worked to rectify the error.
We must rectify this situation immediately.

words.definition: strongly smelling of; suggestive or reminiscent of
sentences: The garden was redolent of roses.
The story was redolent of his own childhood.

words.definition: formidable, especially as an opponent
sentences: She was a redoubtable debater.
The redoubtable warrior won every battle.

words.definition: not needed; exceeding what is necessary
sentences: The redundant paragraph was removed.
His explanation was redundant and repetitive.

words.definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
sentences: The refractory patient refused treatment.
Refractory materials can withstand high heat.

words.definition: to prove a statement or theory to be wrong
sentences: The evidence refuted his claims.
Scientists refuted the outdated theory.

words.definition: to entertain with stories or good food
sentences: Grandfather regaled us with tales of his youth.
The host regaled guests with a feast.

words.definition: to assign to a lower rank or less important position
sentences: He was relegated to a minor role.
The team was relegated to a lower division.

words.definition: unceasingly intense; harsh or inflexible
sentences: The relentless rain flooded the streets.
She pursued her goals with relentless determination.

words.definition: to voluntarily give up or release
sentences: He refused to relinquish control.
She relinquished her claim to the property.

words.definition: unwilling and hesitant
sentences: She was reluctant to share her secrets.
The reluctant witness finally testified.

words.definition: deep regret or guilt for wrongdoing
sentences: He felt remorse for his harsh words.
Without remorse, she continued her deception.

words.definition: a revival of interest or achievement in something
sentences: The city experienced a cultural renaissance.
There was a renaissance in traditional crafts.

words.definition: to formally declare abandonment of a claim or belief
sentences: He renounced his citizenship.
She renounced all material possessions.

words.definition: filled or well-supplied with something
sentences: The book is replete with useful information.
The garden was replete with beautiful flowers.

words.definition: deserving condemnation or blame
sentences: His reprehensible behavior shocked everyone.
The reprehensible crime outraged the community.

words.definition: to rebuke formally; an official criticism
sentences: The teacher reprimanded the cheating student.
He received a reprimand from his supervisor.

words.definition: to express disapproval or disappointment
sentences: She reproached him for breaking his promise.
His actions were beyond reproach.

words.definition: an unprincipled person; morally corrupt
sentences: The reprobate showed no signs of changing.
Society shunned the notorious reprobate.

words.definition: to refuse to accept or be associated with
sentences: The candidate repudiated the offensive remarks.
She repudiated the accusations against her.

words.definition: extremely distasteful; unacceptable
sentences: The idea was repugnant to her values.
His repugnant behavior disgusted everyone.

words.definition: made necessary by circumstances; required
sentences: She lacked the requisite experience for the job.
All requisite documents must be submitted.

words.definition: to revoke, cancel, or repeal
sentences: The company rescinded its earlier decision.
The government rescinded the controversial law.

words.definition: slow to reveal emotions or opinions; restrained
sentences: The reserved man rarely spoke at parties.
She was reserved about sharing personal details.

words.definition: able to recover quickly from difficulties
sentences: Children are remarkably resilient.
The resilient economy recovered faster than expected.

words.definition: firmly determined; unwavering
sentences: She remained resolute in her decision.
The resolute leader refused to back down.

words.definition: to evoke images, memories, or emotions
sentences: Her speech resonated with the audience.
The story resonated with readers everywhere.

words.definition: a short period of rest from something difficult
sentences: The vacation provided a welcome respite.
There was no respite from the relentless heat.

words.definition: impressively beautiful; dazzling
sentences: The bride looked resplendent in her gown.
The resplendent palace amazed visitors.

words.definition: the restoration of something lost or stolen
sentences: The court ordered restitution to the victims.
He made restitution for the damage he caused.

words.definition: unable to remain still or unwilling to be controlled
sentences: The restive crowd grew impatient.
The restive horse refused to be saddled.

words.definition: not revealing one's thoughts readily; reserved
sentences: She was reticent about her personal life.
The reticent witness offered few details.

words.definition: to withdraw a statement or opinion as untrue
sentences: The newspaper was forced to retract the story.
He refused to retract his accusations.

words.definition: feeling or showing deep respect
sentences: The reverent silence honored the fallen soldiers.
She spoke in a reverent tone about her mentor.

words.definition: the art of effective speaking or writing
sentences: His rhetoric inspired the masses.
The politician's rhetoric lacked substance.

words.definition: extremely thorough and careful; strict
sentences: The research underwent rigorous testing.
The rigorous training prepared them well.

words.definition: strong and healthy; vigorous
sentences: Despite his age, he remained robust.
The economy showed robust growth.

words.definition: a dishonest or unprincipled person
sentences: The charming rogue fooled everyone.
A rogue employee leaked the documents.

words.definition: involving basic principles; fundamental
sentences: He had only rudimentary knowledge of cooking.
The rudimentary shelter provided basic protection.

words.definition: to think deeply about something
sentences: She ruminated on the difficult decision.
He spent hours ruminating over the problem.

words.definition: relating to the countryside; simple and unsophisticated
sentences: The rustic cabin had no electricity.
They enjoyed the rustic charm of the village.

words.definition: excessively sweet or sentimental
sentences: The saccharine movie was overly sentimental.
Her saccharine smile seemed fake.

words.definition: regarded as too important or valuable to be interfered with
sentences: Sunday dinners were sacrosanct in their family.
The tradition was considered sacrosanct.

words.definition: having good judgment; wise
sentences: The sagacious leader foresaw the crisis.
Her sagacious advice saved the company.

words.definition: most noticeable or important
sentences: The salient points were highlighted in the report.
Her most salient quality was her honesty.

words.definition: producing good effects; beneficial
sentences: The failure had a salutary effect on his attitude.
The reforms had salutary results.

words.definition: official permission or approval; a penalty
sentences: The project received government sanction.
Economic sanctions were imposed on the country.

words.definition: optimistic or positive, especially in difficult situations
sentences: She remained sanguine despite the setbacks.
His sanguine outlook impressed his colleagues.

words.definition: grimly mocking or cynical
sentences: His sardonic humor offended some people.
She gave a sardonic smile at the irony.

words.definition: to satisfy fully
sentences: The feast satiated everyone's appetite.
Nothing could satiate his thirst for knowledge.

words.definition: to soak thoroughly; to fill completely
sentences: The rain saturated the ground.
Advertisements saturate the media.

words.definition: a learned person; an expert in a particular field
sentences: The mathematical savant solved complex problems easily.
He was considered a savant in his field.

words.definition: barely sufficient or adequate
sentences: There was scant evidence to support the claim.
She paid scant attention to the warning.

words.definition: severely critical; harsh
sentences: The scathing review ruined the play.
She delivered a scathing critique of the policy.

words.definition: a division or split between groups
sentences: The schism divided the church for centuries.
Political differences caused a schism in the party.

words.definition: diligent and thorough; having moral integrity
sentences: The scrupulous accountant checked every figure.
She was scrupulous about following the rules.

words.definition: to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly
sentences: The detective scrutinized every piece of evidence.
Voters scrutinized the candidates' records.

words.definition: relating to religious or political sects; narrow-minded
sentences: Sectarian violence plagued the region.
He opposed sectarian divisions in society.

words.definition: characterized by much sitting and little physical activity
sentences: His sedentary job contributed to weight gain.
A sedentary lifestyle can harm your health.

words.definition: inciting people to rebel against authority
sentences: The seditious pamphlet called for revolution.
He was arrested for seditious activities.

words.definition: causing great excitement or interest
sentences: The sensational news spread quickly.
Her sensational performance earned a standing ovation.

words.definition: prompted by feelings of tenderness or nostalgia
sentences: The old photographs had sentimental value.
She became sentimental at her daughter's graduation.

words.definition: to isolate or hide away
sentences: The jury was sequestered during the trial.
She sequestered herself to finish the novel.

words.definition: the occurrence of fortunate events by chance
sentences: It was serendipity that they met at the airport.
The discovery was a result of serendipity.

words.definition: calm, peaceful, and untroubled
sentences: The serene lake reflected the mountains.
She maintained a serene expression despite the chaos.

words.definition: excessively willing to serve or please others
sentences: His servile manner disgusted his colleagues.
The servile assistant agreed with everything.

words.definition: exceptionally good or great; remarkable
sentences: She possessed singular talent.
The singular event changed history.

words.definition: a person inclined to question accepted opinions
sentences: The skeptic demanded proof for every claim.
Even skeptics were convinced by the evidence.

words.definition: false spoken statements damaging to reputation
sentences: The accusation was pure slander.
He sued for slander after the false claims.

words.definition: lazy; inactive
sentences: His slothful habits prevented success.
The slothful student never completed assignments.

words.definition: the state of being sober; seriousness
sentences: He maintained his sobriety for ten years.
The sobriety of the occasion demanded respect.

words.definition: comfort or consolation in time of distress
sentences: She found solace in music.
His words brought solace to the grieving family.

words.definition: to ask for or try to obtain something
sentences: The charity solicited donations from the public.
He solicited advice from experienced colleagues.

words.definition: showing interest or concern for someone's well-being
sentences: The solicitous nurse attended to every patient.
She was solicitous about her mother's health.

words.definition: the state of being alone
sentences: He enjoyed the solitude of the mountains.
Writers often seek solitude for creativity.

words.definition: dark or dull; serious and gloomy
sentences: The somber mood affected everyone.
She wore somber colors to the funeral.

words.definition: sleepy; drowsy
sentences: The somnolent student struggled to stay awake.
The warm afternoon made everyone somnolent.

words.definition: producing a deep, full, rich sound
sentences: His sonorous voice filled the auditorium.
The sonorous bells could be heard for miles.

words.definition: having refined tastes; complex and developed
sentences: The sophisticated technology impressed experts.
She had sophisticated tastes in art.

words.definition: thinly scattered or scanty
sentences: The sparse vegetation barely survived.
Information about the incident was sparse.

words.definition: superficially plausible but actually wrong
sentences: The specious argument fooled many people.
His specious reasoning fell apart under scrutiny.

words.definition: a visually striking performance or display
sentences: The fireworks were a magnificent spectacle.
He made a spectacle of himself at the party.

words.definition: to form opinions without firm evidence
sentences: Analysts speculated about the company's future.
It would be unwise to speculate without facts.

words.definition: occurring at irregular intervals; scattered
sentences: Sporadic gunfire was heard throughout the night.
Her attendance at meetings was sporadic.

words.definition: not genuine; false or fake
sentences: The spurious claims were quickly debunked.
He used spurious evidence to support his theory.

words.definition: to reject with disdain or contempt
sentences: She spurned his advances.
He spurned their offer of help.

words.definition: extremely dirty and unpleasant
sentences: They lived in squalid conditions.
The squalid apartment needed major repairs.

words.definition: to waste carelessly or extravagantly
sentences: He squandered his inheritance on gambling.
Don't squander this opportunity.

words.definition: showing no activity or growth; still
sentences: The stagnant water bred mosquitoes.
The economy remained stagnant for years.

words.definition: lacking movement, action, or change
sentences: The situation remained static for months.
His career had become static and unfulfilling.

words.definition: firmly loyal and constant; unwavering
sentences: She remained steadfast in her beliefs.
His steadfast support never faltered.

words.definition: enduring pain or hardship without complaint
sentences: The stoic soldier bore his injuries silently.
She maintained a stoic demeanor throughout.

words.definition: a plan or scheme to outwit an opponent
sentences: The clever stratagem surprised the enemy.
She devised a stratagem to win the negotiation.

words.definition: loud, harsh, and grating; aggressively assertive
sentences: His strident voice echoed through the hall.
The strident demands irritated the committee.

words.definition: strict, precise, and exacting
sentences: Stringent safety regulations were enforced.
The stringent requirements eliminated most applicants.

words.definition: spending much time studying or reading
sentences: The studious girl excelled in all subjects.
He made a studious effort to understand the material.

words.definition: to cause to lose enthusiasm; to make useless
sentences: The boring job stultified his creativity.
Rigid rules can stultify innovation.

words.definition: to make someone unable to think clearly; to astonish
sentences: The drug stupefied the patient.
The news stupefied everyone in the room.

words.definition: based on personal feelings or opinions
sentences: Art appreciation is largely subjective.
His subjective view colored the report.

words.definition: of outstanding spiritual or artistic worth
sentences: The sunset was truly sublime.
Her sublime performance moved the audience.

words.definition: ready to conform to authority or the will of others
sentences: The submissive employee never questioned orders.
Years of abuse made her submissive.

words.definition: lower in rank or position
sentences: Subordinate employees reported to the manager.
Personal interests were subordinate to duty.

words.definition: coming after something in time; following
sentences: Subsequent events proved him right.
The subsequent chapters explained the theory.

words.definition: prepared to obey others unquestioningly
sentences: She refused to be subservient to anyone.
The subservient assistant did whatever was asked.

words.definition: to provide evidence to support or prove
sentences: The witness could substantiate his alibi.
More research is needed to substantiate the claim.

words.definition: delicate or precise; not obvious
sentences: The subtle flavor enhanced the dish.
She noticed subtle changes in his behavior.

words.definition: seeking to undermine an established system
sentences: The subversive group plotted against the government.
His subversive ideas challenged the status quo.

words.definition: briefly and clearly expressed
sentences: Her succinct explanation clarified everything.
Keep your answers succinct and to the point.

words.definition: to fail to resist pressure or temptation
sentences: He finally succumbed to the disease.
She refused to succumb to peer pressure.

words.definition: enough; adequate for the purpose
sentences: The evidence was sufficient for a conviction.
They had sufficient food for the journey.

words.definition: existing only on the surface; shallow
sentences: The wound was only superficial.
His superficial analysis missed key details.

words.definition: unnecessary, especially through being more than enough
sentences: The superfluous details cluttered the report.
Anything superfluous was removed from the design.

words.definition: bending easily; flexible
sentences: The gymnast had supple movements.
The supple leather was soft to the touch.

words.definition: to replace someone or something
sentences: Digital cameras supplanted film cameras.
He was supplanted by a younger rival.

words.definition: to ask or beg for something humbly
sentences: She supplicated for mercy from the court.
The people supplicated the king for help.

words.definition: an excessive amount of something
sentences: There was a surfeit of options to choose from.
The surfeit of information overwhelmed students.

words.definition: to suppose without sufficient evidence
sentences: We can only surmise what happened.
She surmised that he was lying.

words.definition: to exceed or be greater than
sentences: Her performance surpassed all expectations.
Sales surpassed last year's total.

words.definition: kept secret because it would not be approved of
sentences: She took a surreptitious glance at her watch.
The surreptitious meeting raised suspicions.

words.definition: to support or maintain over time
sentences: The crops sustain the village.
She could not sustain her initial enthusiasm.

words.definition: a person who acts obsequiously to gain advantage
sentences: The boss surrounded himself with sycophants.
The sycophant praised everything the manager did.

words.definition: the quality of being made up of similar parts
sentences: The building had perfect symmetry.
The symmetry of her face was remarkable.

words.definition: the combination of components to form a connected whole
sentences: The essay was a synthesis of various theories.
The synthesis of the compound was complex.

words.definition: done according to a fixed plan or system
sentences: The systematic approach yielded better results.
They conducted a systematic review of the evidence.
